Immunization within three days of exposure may improve outcomes in children. name, \u201cChicken Pox\u201d is vernacular for the Varicella Zoster Virus. While it has a name that evokes cuteness and is even silly, it is a disease that can, though rarely, claim the life of a child. Prior to the May 1995 introduction of the Varicella vaccine, over four million people would suffer from the Chicken Pox every year- approximately 100 would die.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe first documentation of the virus is credited to the Italian, Giovanni Filippo (1510-1580) of Palermo. Of course, then, it wasn\u2019t called Chicken Pox. It was named as the \u201cVaricella Virus\u201d. Chicken Pox is a strictly English language term for this virus. The French call it Varicelle. The Spanish call the virus Varicela. Only the Germans call Chicken Pox by anything even remotely similar. They call them \u201cWindpocken\u201d.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESo, back to the topic at hand, why IS it called \u201cChicken Pox\u201d? Well, there are many theories, as there usually are to \u201cstreet names\u201d of things. In the 1600s the Englishman, Dr. Richard Morton, misdiagnosed the disease as a milder form of Small Pox. Small Pox, though now eradicated through vaccination, was a fatal disease that killed approximately 300-500 million people during the 20th century alone, and wasn\u2019t any less deadly in Dr. Morton\u2019s time. Because both viruses manifest themselves in the form of lesions on the skin as well as fever, it was easy to see why anyone would connect the two to one another.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn fact, the great 18th century Doctor Samuel Johnson himself is credited in one of the most popular theories as to the origin of the name Chicken Pox. This theory goes that he believed since it was a milder form of Small Pox, it wasn\u2019t as strong or as vicious. Therefore, it was \u201cchicken.\u201d If you\u2019re curious, chicken, meaning \u201ccoward,\u201d first popped up around the 14th century.\u003C\/p\u003E","created_at":"2021-01-05 07:23:15","updated_at":"2021-01-05 07:23:15","vote_count":{"vote_count":2},"totalVotes":2,"num_comments":0,"comments":[],"reactions":[{"reaction_id":1,"reactionable_id":37145878,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":3},{"reaction_id":2,"reactionable_id":37145878,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":1}],"user":{"name":"LESHEM ZEMIRA ABBASI","avatar":"https:\/\/lh3.googleusercontent.com\/a-\/AOh14GhZRw8syFmUOBdMJvIZDtNKGG-W4yNwz3ldGKE5=s96-c","username":"Leshem","id":1070608,"user_type":null},"images":[]},{"id":37145896,"question_id":3398472,"user_id":1121468,"body":"\u003Cp\u003EThe name chickenpox has been around for centuries, and there are a number of theories as to how it got its name. ve been\u003C\/p\u003E","created_at":"2021-01-07 04:50:44","updated_at":"2021-01-07 04:50:44","vote_count":{"vote_count":1},"totalVotes":1,"num_comments":0,"comments":[],"reactions":[],"user":{"name":"ajom","avatar":"https:\/\/img.answers.com\/answ\/image\/upload\/w_avatarSize,h_avatarSize,dpr_2.0\/v1574112807\/avatars\/unicorn.png","username":"ajom","id":1132131,"user_type":null},"images":[]},{"id":37151169,"question_id":3398472,"user_id":1132538,"body":"\u003Cp\u003EChickenpox: A highly infectious viral disease also known medically as varicella -- in many countries, this disease is always called \u0026quot;varicella\u0026quot; -- that causes a blister-like rash, itching, fatigue and fever. The rash crops up first on the face and trunk and can spread over the entire body resulting in 250 to 500 itchy blisters.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EChickenpox (Varicella)\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EChickenpox is highly infectious. The virus spreads from person to person by direct contact or through the air by coughing or sneezing. It takes from 10-21 days after contact with an infected person for someone to develop chickenpox. People with chickenpox are contagious a day or two before the rash appears and until all blisters have formed scabs.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn children, chickenpox most commonly causes an illness that lasts about 5-10 days. Children usually miss 5 or 6 days of school or childcare due to their chickenpox. Their symptoms may include high fever, severe itching, an uncomfortable rash, dehydration, and headache. About 1 child in 10 has a complication from chickenpox -- infected skin lesions, other infections, dehydration from vomiting or diarrhea, exacerbation (worsening) of asthma and pneumonia -- that is serious enough to warrant a visit to the doctor.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECertain people are especially likely to have a serious illness from chickenpox. These at-risk groups include infants, adolescents, and adults and people with weak immune systems from either illnesses or from medications such long-term steroids or chemotherapy.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EChickenpox has nothing at all to do with chicken. The name was meant to distinguish this \u0026quot;weak\u0026quot; form of the pox from smallpox. \u0026quot;Chicken\u0026quot; is used here, as in \u0026quot;chickenhearted,\u0026quot; to mean weak or timid. The \u0026quot;pox\u0026quot; of chickenpox is no major matter unless it becomes infected (through scratching) or occurs in an immunodeficient person.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHowever, there can be very major problems from chickenpox including pneumonia and encephalitis and reactivation of the same herpes virus is responsible for shingles (zoster). Chickenpox is responsible for more deaths than measles (rubeola), mumps, whooping cough (pertussis) and H. flu (Haemophilus influenzae type B) meningitis combined. Contrary to what many people believe, chickenpox is by no means a mild disease.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA healthy person can die from the disease. From 1990 to 1994, before there was a vaccine available, there were about 50 chickenpox deaths in children and 50 chickenpox deaths in adults every year in the US. Most of these persons were healthy or did not have a medical illness such as cancer that placed them at higher risk of getting severe chickenpox. Most of the healthy adults who die from chickenpox contract the disease from their unvaccinated children.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe current aim in the US is to achieve universal (or come as close as possible to universal) immunization of children with the chickenpox vaccine. The rationale for childhood chickenpox vaccination is not just to protect the children but also to protect everyone with whom they come in contact, including adults (who can die from the chickenpox) and pregnant women (so that the unborn baby does not get chickenpox). Because chickenpox in children is usually not serious, some people think it is safe to let children get the disease. However, it is never possible to predict who will have a mild case of chickenpox and who will have a serious or even deadly case of disease. Now that there is a safe and effective vaccine available, it is not worth taking this risk.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA person can get chickenpox more than once but it is uncommon to do so. For most people, one infection is thought to confer lifelong immunity.\u003C\/p\u003E","created_at":"2021-01-07 06:03:09","updated_at":"2021-01-07 or popularly known as chicken pox, was first described by Giovanni Filippo, in 1500 in Italy. After, Richard Morton, an English doctor, in 1600 gave the name of chicken pox to what he thought was a form of smallpox. Later, in 1700, another English physician, William Heberden, confirmed the existence of chicken pox. It is a disease of primary viral infection, caused by an RNA virus, the varicella-zoster, of the Herpes-viridae family, has a benign character, but its severity increases with age, so young people, adults and immunocompromised people are at higher risk for complications. The symptoms of chickenpox are fever, nausea, anorexia, and its main characteristic is the appearance of maculopapular lesions, which evolve and reach a vesicular aspect throughout the body. Currently the vaccine is highly effective against chicken pox and helps prevent disease.\u003C\/p\u003E","created_at":"2021-01-08 17:29:18","updated_at":"2021-01-08 17:29:18","vote_count":{"vote_count":2},"totalVotes":2,"num_comments":0,"comments":[],"reactions":[{"reaction_id":1,"reactionable_id":37154605,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":1}],"user":{"name":"Davi Do Carmo","avatar":"https:\/\/lh3.googleusercontent.com\/a-\/AOh14Gh2XvwHXr6x6ixCeRsrcN9wvS7FPKKHrbaq7hbV8Q=s96-c","username":"davidocarmo","id":1140543,"user_type":null},"images":[]},{"id":37154786,"question_id":3398472,"user_id":921390,"body":"\u003Cp\u003EThe name, \u201cChicken Pox\u201d is vernacular for the Varicella Zoster Virus. While it has a name that evokes cuteness and is even silly, it is a disease that can, though rarely, claim the life of a child. Prior to the May 1995 introduction of the Varicella vaccine, over four million people would suffer from the Chicken Pox every year- approximately 100 would die.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe first documentation of the virus is credited to the Italian, Giovanni Filippo (1510-1580) of Palermo. Of course, then, it wasn\u2019t called Chicken Pox. It was named as the \u201cVaricella Virus\u201d. Chicken Pox is a strictly English language term for this virus. The French call it Varicelle. The Spanish call the virus Varicela. Only the Germans call Chicken Pox by anything even remotely similar. They call them \u201cWindpocken\u201d.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESo, back to the topic at hand, why IS it called \u201cChicken Pox\u201d? Well, there are many theories, as there usually are to \u201cstreet names\u201d of things. In the 1600s the Englishman, Dr. Richard Morton, misdiagnosed the disease as a milder form of Small Pox. Small Pox, though now eradicated through vaccination, was a fatal disease that killed approximately 300-500 million people during the 20th century alone, and wasn\u2019t any less deadly in Dr. Morton\u2019s time. Because both viruses manifest themselves in the form of lesions on the skin as well as fever, it was easy to see why anyone would connect the two to one another.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn fact, the great 18th century Doctor Samuel Johnson himself is credited in one of the most popular theories as to the origin of the name Chicken Pox. This theory goes that he believed since it was a milder form of Small Pox, it wasn\u2019t as strong or as vicious. Therefore, it was \u201cchicken.\u201d If you\u2019re curious, chicken, meaning \u201ccoward,\u201d first popped up around the 14th century.\u003C\/p\u003E","created_at":"2021-01-08 It can also be distributed in other seasons. It is mainly concentrated in children under 10 years of age. In the early stages of onset, children may have symptoms of general discomfort such as fever, which are mainly manifested in Skin rashes appear on the trunk, limbs, head and face, and may be red papules in the early stage, which may gradually become blisters of varying sizes, which gradually dry, scab, and fall off, and the rashes may appear in batches. Because both viruses manifest themselves in the form of lesions on the skin as well as fever, it was easy to see why anyone would connect the two to one another.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn fact, the great 18th century Doctor Samuel Johnson himself is credited in one of the most popular theories as to the origin of the name Chicken Pox. This theory goes that he believed since it was a milder form of Small Pox, it wasn\u2019t as strong or as vicious. Therefore, it was \u201cchicken.\u201d If you\u2019re curious, chicken, meaning \u201ccoward,\u201d first popped up around the 14th century.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHowever, given that the first documented instance of \u201cChicken Pox\u201d comes from the 1727 Chambers Encyclopedia\u2013 when Dr. Johnson would have been just 18 years old- if the \u201cchicken\/coward\u201d theory is correct, we\u2019re more than a little skeptical that the name was thought up by him.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn 1767, Dr. William Heberden made the discovery that Chicken Pox and Small Pox are NOT from the same virus.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis brings the theory number two. The Middle English language had the words \u201cYicche\u201d or \u201cIcchen\u201d meaning, \u201cto itch.\u201d The Old English word for \u201cto itch\u201d is \u201cGiccan.\u201d So it seems possible that \u201cChicken Pox\u201d may simply be a bastardized version of \u201cGiccan\/Yicche\/Icchen\/Itching\u201d + \u201cPox.\u201d\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBeyond those, people have voiced theories that generally aren\u2019t given as much credence, such as that the red spots look like a chicken pecked the victim. Another idea is that they were named for their similarity in appearance to \u201cchick peas\u201d.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow let\u2019s look at the other word- \u201cPox.\u201d Pox, which first popped up around the late 15th century, is simply an alternate way to spell the plural of \u201cpockes\u201d, which ultimately derives from the Old English \u201cpocc,\u201d meaning \u201cpustule, blister, ulcer.\u201d\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESo depending on which of the two main theories you want to believe, Chicken Pox would then either literally be \u201ccowardly\/lesser blisters\u201d. Alternatively, it could simply be a bastardized way of saying \u201cIcchen (as in itchy) Blisters,\u201d which for those of us who\u2019ve had it, we can all agree Chicken Pox is that. So take your pick. There just isn\u2019t enough documented evidence for us to know for sure on this one.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESource: Internet\u003C\/p\u003E","created_at":"2021-02-06 06:26:24","updated_at":"2021-02-06 06:26:24","vote_count":{"vote_count":1},"totalVotes":1,"num_comments":0,"comments":[],"reactions":[],"user":{"name":"Larissa Willard","avatar":"https:\/\/lh3.googleusercontent.com\/a-\/AOh14GjgVY1raZgPDI-Vezzn8Vo8AIOUgVVTJM_nMihn=s96-c","username":"larissawillard","id":1041152,"user_type":null},"images":[]},{"id":37204679,"question_id":3398472,"user_id":1292347,"body":"\u003Cp\u003EThe term used was unclear, possibly because smallpox is a relatively mild disease. [16]  It has been suggested that it is derived from chickpeas, based on the similarity in the vesicles, [16] [17] or that it may come from a rash that resembles a chicken pecker, or that the idea of \u200b\u200bdisease may have originated from chickens. Organist Ray Nelson played \u201cclassic and soulful compositions\u201d before the Cubs took on the Cardinals at Wrigley Field. He had to stop before the game started, however, because he was playing copyrighted songs that could\u2019ve been picked up by radio broadcasts.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe baseball-stadium organ caught on quickly, however; the following season, the Brooklyn Dodgers hired a permanent organist, and their popularity increased through the mid-20th century. Sort of a group, they do not have the contrary exceptional skills or immunities. But over the 4th edition, the monstrous humanoid was merged to the humanoid type.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIs Hold Person a good spell in 5e dnd?\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHold Person 5e is one of the most potent spells within the game vs. humanoid opponents. Yes, during an on one, if they fail one rescue, then you\u2019ve got to spend your speech preventing an enemy from using a turn, and it isn\u2019t beneficial. Nevertheless, DnD might be a team game. During that one twist, all your allies are attacking with advantage, and if they are adjacent, they\u2019re mechanically getting crits. That may ruin any boss fight versus a humanoid opponent.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHeld creatures can\u2019t move or talk, but they are still conscious of the environment and may use skills not requiring speech or movement. Being held does not stop time, so ongoing damage like wounds, disease, or poison will impact the creature.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhat is a Humanoid in 5e?\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe text of this spell specifies a humanoid so that I took this to mean explicitly of the humanoid type. But looking at hold monster says\u201da creature.\u201d It calls out, significantly, that it does not affect undead (which hold Person doesn\u2019t specify).\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAt the dining table, as a\u201ddecide right now and revisit later to keep the game going. \u201d I ruled that the caster could attempt it but that the vampire would have an advantage on its saving throw as a compromise. The caster finally decided to do something else somewhat anyway.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EUpon further reflection, I believe I was right in my first decision that the text primarily employs the keywords\u201dhumanoid.\u201d At the same time, vampires have the undead kind, and so it would not work (mostly since hold monster, the bigger-better version, does not work on undead at all). But I am interested in what anybody else may have to say before I make my final ruling.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDead have always been resistant to\u201dcharm, hold and sleep\u201d charms in the dawn of the match. I would imagine that\u2019s why hold monster [or Individual ] doesn\u2019t work on undead.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EUndead don\u2019t sleep. They\u2019re either mindless or have minds fueled by negative energies or consumed by destructive emotions. There is a chemical reaction that occurs when you cut an onion; you damage the onion\u0027s cells, and the enzyme (Syn-ropanethial-S-oxide) that escapes acts as a lachrymatory agent. When that agent hits your eyes, it mixes with your tears to make sulfuric acid, and your tear ducts activate in an attempt to wash out the contamination.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESo, that being said:\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Col\u003E\u003Cli\u003EWearing goggles is the most obvious answer. It may look a little silly, but it\u0027s the easiest way to prevent the onion\u0027s enzyme from reaching the eyes.\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003ESharpening your knife beforehand limits the damage to the onion cells, thus releasing fewer gases.\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003ESpraying your cutting board with vinegar slows down the chemical reaction. It does, however, make your onions smell\/taste like vinegar.\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAlways placing the cut side down will minimize the chemicals released into the open air.\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003ECutting onions under the kitchen vent will remove some of the chemicals from the air.\u003C\/li\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAnd finally, try not to form an emotional bond with Chill your onions\u003C\/strong\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELet your onions chill in the fridge, pop them in the freezer for a while (about 15 minutes), or just dunk them in an ice water bath for a little while.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EGetting an onion nice and cold helps prevent eye irritation by reducing the amount of LF released through cutting.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E2. Fan away the fumes\u003C\/strong\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECut your onions near your eye range or a small fan. The circulating air will blow the LF away from your eyes and help keep you tear-free.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E3. Cut under cold water\u003C\/strong\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis works like chilling your onions and using a fan \u2014 cold running water both lowers the temperature and reduces the amount of LF reaching your eyes.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E4. Sharpen that knife\u003C\/strong\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESharp knives slash the onion more easily without causing too much damage to the onion thereby minimizing the release of LF.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E5. Work on your knife skills\u003C\/strong\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHone your skills to work more quickly and confidently, and there will be fewer tears.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELastly, if all this refuses to work, you can just wear goggles.\u003C\/p\u003E","created_at":"2021-01-17 14:56:52","updated_at":"2021-01-17 14:56:52","vote_count":{"vote_count":0},"totalVotes":0,"num_comments":0,"comments":[],"reactions":[],"user":{"name":"juhudix","avatar":"https:\/\/img.answers.com\/answ\/image\/upload\/w_avatarSize,h_avatarSize,dpr_2.0\/v1574112807\/avatars\/alien.png","username":"juhudix","id":1176870,"user_type":null},"images":[]},{"id":37174684,"question_id":186174761,"user_id":1120610,"body":"\u003Cp\u003EDeep in water before\u003C\/p\u003E","created_at":"2021-01-18 00:25:43","updated_at":"2021-01-18 00:25:43","vote_count":{"vote_count":1},"totalVotes":1,"num_comments":0,"comments":[],"reactions":[],"user":{"name":"Pranit Chettri 1993","avatar":"https:\/\/lh3.googleusercontent.com\/--aysmxBFMY4\/AAAAAAAAAAI\/AAAAAAAAAAA\/AMZuucmYU-8cj131C4eFxPz2vldC9FJXqw\/s96-c\/photo.jpg","username":"pranitchettri","id":1120610,"user_type":null},"images":[]},{"id":37174685,"question_id":186174761,"user_id":1120610,"body":"\u003Cp\u003EDeep in water before\u003C\/p\u003E","created_at":"2021-01-18 00:26:13","updated_at":"2021-01-18 00:26:13","vote_count":{"vote_count":1},"totalVotes":1,"num_comments":0,"comments":[],"reactions":[],"user":{"name":"Pranit Chettri 1993","avatar":"https:\/\/lh3.googleusercontent.com\/--aysmxBFMY4\/AAAAAAAAAAI\/AAAAAAAAAAA\/AMZuucmYU-8cj131C4eFxPz2vldC9FJXqw\/s96-c\/photo.jpg","username":"pranitchettri","id":1120610,"user_type":null},"images":[]},{"id":37174814,"question_id":186174761,"user_id":1181974,"body":"\u003Cp\u003EPegue uma t\u00e1bua de cortar carne coloque a cebola em cima  descascada. most foolproof method is to use a sharp knife. There is a chemical reaction that occurs when you cut an onion; you damage the onion\u0027s cells, and the enzyme (Syn-ropanethial-S-oxide) that escapes acts as a lachrymatory agent. When that agent hits your eyes, it mixes with your tears to make sulfuric acid, and your tear ducts activate in an attempt to wash out the contamination.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESo, that being said:\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWearing goggles is the most obvious answer. It may look a little silly, but it\u0027s the easiest way to prevent the onion\u0027s enzyme from reaching the eyes.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESharpening your knife beforehand limits the damage to the onion cells, thus releasing fewer gases.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESpraying your cutting board with vinegar slows down the chemical reaction. order to prevent crying, it helps to understand why it happens. There is a chemical reaction that occurs when you cut an onion; you damage the onion\u0027s cells, and the enzyme (Syn-ropanethial-S-oxide) that escapes acts as a lachrymatory agent. When that agent hits your eyes, it mixes with your tears to make sulfuric acid, and your tear ducts activate in an attempt to wash out the contamination.\u003C\/u\u003E\u003C\/strong\u003E\u003C\/em\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cu\u003ESo, that being said:\u003C\/u\u003E\u003C\/strong\u003E\u003C\/em\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cu\u003EWearing goggles is the most obvious answer. It may look a little silly, but it\u0027s the easiest way to prevent the onion\u0027s enzyme from reaching the eyes.\u003C\/u\u003E\u003C\/strong\u003E\u003C\/em\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cu\u003ESharpening your knife beforehand limits the damage to the onion cells, thus releasing fewer gases.\u003C\/u\u003E\u003C\/strong\u003E\u003C\/em\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cu\u003ESpraying your cutting board with vinegar slows down the chemical reaction. It does, however, make your onions smell\/taste like vinegar.\u003C\/u\u003E\u003C\/strong\u003E\u003C\/em\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cu\u003EAlways placing the cut side down will minimize the chemicals released into the open air.\u003C\/u\u003E\u003C\/strong\u003E\u003C\/em\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cu\u003ECutting onions under the kitchen vent will remove some of the chemicals from the air.\u003C\/u\u003E\u003C\/strong\u003E\u003C\/em\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cu\u003EAnd finally, try not to form an emotional bond with book in any format may read the same, but it seems there\u2019s something about the smell of print that e-books just can\u2019t capture\u2014for now.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EEarlier this summer, New York Times tech blogger Nick Bilton wrote about wandering into a West Village bookstore on a visit to New York:\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u201cI immediately felt a sense of nostalgia that I haven\u2019t felt in a long time. The scent of physical books\u2014the paper, the ink, the glue\u2014can conjure up memories of a summer day spent reading on a beach, a fall afternoon in a coffee shop, or an overstuffed chair by a fireplace as rain patters on a windowsill.\u201d\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut amidst this nostalgic reverie, he considers the advantages of e-books: their search functionality, ease of transport, the ability to share favorite passages with friends. He leaves the bookstore without buying anything.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYet for some, the added conveniences of electronic books can never make up for the loss of the physical experience of reading a print book. The author Ray Bradbury famously was never a fan of e-books:\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u201cThose aren\u2019t books. . . . A computer does not smell. There are two perfumes to a book. If a book is new, it smells great. If a book is old, it smells even better. It smells like ancient Egypt. A book has got to smell.\u201d\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAccording to Bradbury, e-books themselves \u201csmell like burned fuel.\u201d\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThough none were as caustic as Bradbury, one of the things that struck me in the responses of our online panel was the ambivalence of these avid readers (and e-book borrowers) toward the rise of e-books. Many echoed the same thought: \u201cNothing can replace the feel and smell of a physical book.\u201d\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAs another panelist explained:\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u201cI thoroughly enjoy reading from my Kindle. I am honestly surprised because I am an absolute bibliophile. I love the touch, the smell, everything about a paper book. I would find it shameful if paper books were not longer published or made available. For me, my e-reader will NEVER take the place of a paper book, but it does have its own niche.\u201d\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHowever, some patrons noted the downside of the \u201cused book smell.\u201d One wrote:\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u201cI\u2019ve always been a book lover, but not having to deal with dirty, smelly, broken books is really nice. Instead of borrowing [print] books from the library, I\u2019ll buy the e-book if the library\u2019s e-book isn\u2019t available.\u201d\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnother said that she doesn\u2019t even borrow print books from the library because she is allergic to perfume, \u201cand the physical books are usually smelly. E-books, on the other hand, have no odor.\u201d\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn fact, one patron felt that having fewer books at the library made the library more conducive to reading:\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u201cI like that the libraries are not as cluttered with old smelly books now that the computers and e-book formats are around. It makes the libraries feel less like old bookstores and more like a living room waiting for readers to sit down and read.\u201d\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFinally, the results of our national survey indicate that while the lack of a \u201cgood book smell\u201d is not a deal-breaker for most readers, it\u2019s certainly not irrelevant.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhen we asked readers what they like most about reading books, they gave a variety of responses. Many mentioned the joys of learning, entertainment, or relaxation, but a few (2%) said the physical properties of books\u2014their feel and smell\u2014was their favorite part of reading. And among Americans who don\u2019t currently own an e-reader (like a Kindle or Nook), about 16% said the main reason is that they just prefer print books in general.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThough e-book readers clearly prefer e-books to print in many situations, they may not need to sacrifice all the tactile pleasure of the printed page. In fact, nostalgic e-book readers can now recapture that new- or old-book scent with perfumes such as In The Library and Paper Passion (shown at top). And for the budget reader, Smell of Books\u2122 claims to offer an \u201caerosol e-book enhancer,\u201d available in scents ranging from its \u201cNew Book Smell\u201d and \u201cClassic Musty Smell\u201d (shown below) to \u201cCrunchy Bacon Scent.\u201d Note\u2014Unlike the perfumes mentioned above, this product appears to be tongue-in-cheek.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI\u2019ll close with the words of an online panelist who described her own internal compromise between the pleasures of print and the ease of e-books. \u201cThe joy of smelling turning pages can\u2019t be matched by an e-book, but the joy of the story from an e-book can turn someone into a physical book reader,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd the more we read the better we all are.\u201d\u003C\/p\u003E","created_at":"2020-12-06 16:42:19","updated_at":"2020-12-06 smell of fresh ink (sometimes). They get all their material new. Hopefully, it gets sold fairly quickly.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELibraries do get new materials all the time, but the vast majority is older. Our oldest books are over 100 years old. (Those are in the reference section, and don\u0027t circulate.) Once loaned out, items come back smelling like cigarettes, perfume, cooking, weed, etc. If they smell very noticeably, and it doesn\u0027t go away quickly, ours go into the circular file. Not all libraries can afford to do that.\u003C\/p\u003E","created_at":"2020-12-10 02:14:08","updated_at":"2020-12-10 02:14:08","vote_count":{"vote_count":1},"totalVotes":1,"num_comments":0,"comments":[],"reactions":[{"reaction_id":1,"reactionable_id":37106931,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":2},{"reaction_id":3,"reactionable_id":37106931,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":1}],"user":{"name":"Kaylyn","avatar":"https:\/\/lh3.googleusercontent.com\/a-\/AOh14GhYgb1IfdBfhTTduQJq1tLC0a3WdU_NjXbZn4c8oA=s96-c","username":"kaykay_","id":918661,"user_type":null},"images":[]},{"id":37109443,"question_id":410224113,"user_id":860910,"body":"\u003Cp\u003EEveryone\u2019s familiar with the smell of old books, the weirdly intoxicating scent that haunts libraries and second-hand book stores. Similarly, who doesn\u2019t enjoy riffling through the pages of a newly purchased book and breathing in the crisp aroma of new paper and freshly printed ink? As with all aromas, the origins can be traced back to a number of chemical constituents, so we can examine the processes and compounds that can contribute to both.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAs far as the smell of new books goes, it\u2019s actually quite difficult to pinpoint specific compounds, for a number of reasons. Firstly, there seems to be a scarcity of scientific research that\u2019s been carried out on the subject \u2013 to be fair, it\u2019s understandable why it might not exactly be high up on the priority list. Secondly, the variation in the chemicals used to manufacture books also means that it\u2019s an aroma that will vary from book to book. Add to this the fact that there are literally hundreds of compounds involved, and it becomes clearer why it evades attribution to a small selection of chemicals.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIt\u2019s likely that the bulk of \u2018new book smell\u2019 can be put down to three main sources: the paper itself (and the chemicals used in its manufacture), the inks used to print the book, and the adhesives used in the book-binding process.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe manufacture of paper requires the use of chemicals at several stages. Large amounts of paper are made from wood pulp (though it can also be made from cotton and textiles) \u2013 chemicals such as sodium hydroxide, often referred to in this context as \u2018caustic soda\u2019, can be added to increase pH and cause fibres in the pulp to swell. The fibres are then bleached with a number of other chemicals, including hydrogen peroxide; then, they are mixed with large amounts of water. This water will contain additives to modify the properties of the the paper \u2013 for example, AKD (alkyl ketene dimer) is commonly used as a \u2018sizing agent\u2019 to improve the water-resistance of the paper.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMany other chemicals are also used \u2013 this is just a very rough overview. The upshot of this is that some of these chemicals can contribute, through their reactions or otherwise, to the release of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) into the air, the odours of which we can detect. The same is true of chemicals used in the inks, and the adhesives used in the books. A number of different adhesives are used for book-binding, many of which are based on organic \u2018co-polymers\u2019 \u2013 large numbers of smaller molecules chemically chained together.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAs stated, differences in paper, adhesives, and inks used will influence the \u2018new book smell\u2019, so not all new books will smell the same \u2013 perhaps the reason why no research has yet attempted to definitively define the aroma.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAn aroma that has had much more research carried out around it, however, is that of old books. There\u2019s a reason for this, as it\u2019s been investigated as a potential method for assessing the condition of old books, by monitoring the concentrations of different organic compounds that they give off. As a result, we can be a little more certain on some of the many compounds that contribute to the smell.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EGenerally, it is the chemical breakdown of compounds within paper that leads to the production of \u2018old book smell\u2019. Paper contains, amongst other chemicals, cellulose, and smaller amounts of lignin \u2013 much less in more modern books than in books from more than one hundred years ago. Both of these originate from the trees the paper is made from; finer papers will contain much less lignin than, for example, newsprint. In trees, lignin helps bind cellulose fibres together, keeping the wood stiff; it\u2019s also responsible for old paper\u2019s yellowing with age, as oxidation reactions cause it to break down into acids, which then help break down cellulose.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u2018Old book smell\u2019 is derived from this chemical degradation. Modern, high quality papers will undergo chemical processing to remove lignin, but breakdown of cellulose in the paper can still occur (albeit at a much slower rate) due to the presence of acids in the surroundings. These reactions, referred to generally as \u2018acid hydrolysis\u2019, produce a wide range of volatile organic compounds, many of which are likely to contribute to the smell of old books. A selected number of compounds have had their contributions pinpointed: benzaldehyde adds an almond-like scent; vanillin adds a vanilla-like scent; ethyl benzene and toluene impart sweet odours; and 2-ethyl hexanol has a \u2018slightly floral\u2019 contribution. Other aldehydes and alcohols produced by these reactions have low odour thresholds and also contribute.\u003C\/p\u003E","created_at":"2020-12-11 18:01:08","updated_at":"2020-12-11 18:01:08","vote_count":{"vote_count":1},"totalVotes":1,"num_comments":0,"comments":[],"reactions":[{"reaction_id":1,"reactionable_id":37109443,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":1},{"reaction_id":2,"reactionable_id":37109443,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":2},{"reaction_id":3,"reactionable_id":37109443,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":1},{"reaction_id":4,"reactionable_id":37109443,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":1}],"user":{"name":"Heidi assume you\u2019re referring to the difference between the glorious mustiness of a library and the glorious plastic y newness of a bookstore. That\u2019s probably due to the fact that as paper ages, the cellulose within it decays, letting off that sweet, sweet book smell. Bookstore books haven\u2019t had as much time to decay (unless it\u2019s a used bookstore), leading to that different smell. Fabletics creates premium activewear, yoga pants, fitness apparel, leggings, capris, joggers \u0026amp; more! Fabletics\u0027 clothing inspires you to stay active, whether that means competing in competitions, sweating in the studio, or chasing after your kids. As a book age, the chemical compounds like glue, paper, ink begin to break down. And, as they do, they release volatile compounds the source of the smell.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis is the main reason for the difference in smell.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA book in any format may read the same, but it seems there\u2019s something about the smell of print that e-books just can\u2019t capture\u2014for now.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EEarlier this summer, New York Times tech blogger Nick Bilton wrote about wandering into a West Village bookstore on a visit to New York:\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u201cI immediately felt a sense of nostalgia that I haven\u2019t felt in a long time. The scent of physical books\u2014the paper, the ink, the glue\u2014can conjure up memories of a summer day spent reading on a beach, a fall afternoon in a coffee shop, or an overstuffed chair by a fireplace as rain patters on a windowsill.\u201d\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut amidst this nostalgic reverie, he considers the advantages of e-books: their search functionality, ease of transport, the ability to share favourite passages with friends. He leaves the bookstore without buying anything.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYet for some, the added conveniences of electronic books can never make up for the loss of the physical experience of reading a print book. The author Ray Bradbury famously was never a fan of e-books:\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u201cThose aren\u2019t books. . . . A computer does not smell. There are two perfumes to a book. If a book is new, it smells great. If a book is old, it smells even better. It smells like ancient Egypt. A book has got to smell.\u201d\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHowever, some patrons noted the downside of the \u201cused book smell.\u201d One wrote:\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u201cI\u2019ve always been a book lover, but not having to deal with dirty, smelly, broken books is really nice. Instead of borrowing [print] books from the library, I\u2019ll buy the e-book if the library\u2019s e-book isn\u2019t available.\u201d\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnother said that she doesn\u2019t even borrow print books from the library because she is allergic to perfume, \u201cand the physical books are usually smelly. E-books, on the other hand, have no odour.\u201d\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn fact, one patron felt that having fewer books at the library made the library more conducive to reading:\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u201cI like that the libraries are not as cluttered with old smelly books now that the computers and e-book formats are around. It makes the libraries feel less like old bookstores and more like a living room waiting for readers to sit down and read.\u201d\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFinally, the results of our national survey indicate that while the lack of a \u201cgood book smell\u201d is not a deal-breaker for most readers, it\u2019s certainly not irrelevant.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhen we asked readers what they like most about reading books, they gave a variety of responses. Many mentioned the joys of learning, entertainment, or relaxation, but a few (2%) said the physical properties of books\u2014their feel and smell\u2014was their favourite part of reading. And among Americans who don\u2019t currently own an e-reader (like a Kindle or Nook), about 16% said the main reason is that they just prefer print books in general.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThough e-book readers clearly prefer e-books to print in many situations, they may not need to sacrifice all the tactile pleasure of the printed page. In fact, nostalgic e-book readers can now recapture that new- or old-book scent with perfumes such as In The Library and Paper Passion (shown at top). And for the budget reader, Smell of Books\u2122 claims to offer an \u201caerosol e-book enhancer,\u201d available in scents ranging from its \u201cNew Book Smell\u201d and \u201cClassic Musty Smell\u201d (shown below) to \u201cCrunchy Bacon Scent.\u201d Note\u2014Unlike the perfumes mentioned above, this product appears to be tongue-in-cheek.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI\u2019ll close with the words of an online panellist who described her own internal compromise between the pleasures of print and the ease of e-books. \u201cThe joy of smelling turning pages can\u2019t be matched by Also, there is no volcanic activity on the moon to change the lunar surface features. Nothing gets washed away, and nothing gets folded back inside.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHowever, the Moon is exposed to bombardment by meteorites, which change the surface. wind or water on the moon because it has no atmosphere and all the water on the surface is frozen as ice. Also, there is no volcanic activity on the moon to change the lunar surface features. Nothing gets washed away, and nothing gets folded back inside.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHowever, the Moon is exposed to bombardment by meteorites, which change the surface. have fevers.  Colds are usually caused by the rhinovirus (up to 40% of colds), or Coronaviruses (about 20%), but there are more than 200 viruses that can cause the common cold.  Also questions about the seasonal flu, also called \u0022regular flu\u0022, caused mostly by Type A and Type B Influenza viruses.  Flu starts with similar \r\nsymptoms as a cold only it hits faster and harder and usually includes fever in adults. Although the \u0022stomach flu\u0022 is a common term, it is not a real diagnosis. The proper medical term for stomach flu is gastroenteritis (an intestinal disease, sometimes viral but also bacterial), it is often mistaken for influenza because the flu can sometimes include vomiting and diarrhea. As a result of the cold weather and the entry of the autumn season, the periods of sun surfaces decrease, so hormonal changes occur within the bodies of these birds that make them migrate to warmer southern places with longer days and longer periods of lighting. We find these birds crossing the seas and migrating singly and not in groups. Most of them migrate from central Mexico to Alaska and return again to their homelands and during this trip they fly at a flight speed of about 27 miles \/ hour and during their flight they are They\u0026rsquo;re amphibians.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIt\u0026rsquo;s understandable to mistake the slender, long-tailed, little-legged creatures for lizards, but they\u0026rsquo;re actually closer relatives to frogs. Take a look at them\u0026mdash;you can kind of see it! Like frogs and other amphibians, salamander babies have gills and live in the water, then move to moist land as adults. That\u0026rsquo;s because their adult skin absorbs water but also loses it, so they need constant replenishment.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELizards (and all reptiles) don\u0026rsquo;t need to live on moist land. 10:07:50","vote_count":{"vote_count":1},"totalVotes":1,"num_comments":0,"comments":[],"reactions":[],"user":{"name":"hawa mithu","avatar":"https:\/\/lh3.googleusercontent.com\/a-\/AOh14Gi63Eg4l0LBI0Lyep5mcmzbKc5_FSYpjuOb-Opm=s96-c","username":"reallyhawa","id":1176883,"user_type":null},"images":[]},{"id":37208683,"question_id":412437068,"user_id":1311111,"body":"\u003Cp\u003E\u0644\u0627 \u0627\u0644\u0633\u0645\u0646\u062f\u0631 \u0644\u064a\u0633 \u0645\u0646 \u0623\u0646\u0648\u0627\u0639 \u0627\u0644\u0633\u062d\u0627\u0644\u0649 \u0623\u0646\u0647 \u062d\u064a\u0648\u0627\u0646\u003C\/p\u003E","created_at":"2021-02-09 21:34:09","updated_at":"2021-02-09 21:34:09","vote_count":{"vote_count":1},"totalVotes":1,"num_comments":0,"comments":[],"reactions":[],"user":{"name":"Medo Essa","avatar":"https:\/\/lh3.googleusercontent.com\/a-\/AOh14GguxyqUKk_D3aRhlxa6Nlj-efkxn6UPlHbMKPuTBA=s96-c","username":"ysy","id":1311111,"user_type":null},"images":[]},{"id":37275895,"question_id":412437068,"user_id":1419961,"body":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cem\u003EAbout Salamanders\u003C\/em\u003E\u003C\/u\u003E\u003C\/strong\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESalamanders are secretive, so much so that most people never encounter them. But because of their sensitive skin and specific habitat requirements, these shy creatures can tell us a lot about the health of our environment. Two salamander species are listed as Special Concern in Massachusetts under the state\u2019s endangered species act, and one is listed as Threatened.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EIdentification\u003C\/strong\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBecause of their slender bodies and long tails, salamanders look somewhat like lizards, and people often confuse the two. But lizards are reptiles, whereas salamanders are amphibians (as are frogs and toads). Lizards have scales and claws; salamanders do not. Lizards typically have dry skin; most salamanders stay moist, and many of them use their wet skin as a surface through which to breathe.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAll salamanders belong to the amphibian order Caudata, from the Latin word for \u201ctailed\u201d. Newts and mudpuppies are types of salamanders.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EBehavior\u003C\/strong\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EUnlike frogs, salamanders are rarely vocal. Instead, they communicate using touch and chemicals.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETo avoid predators, they may exude bad-tasting substances. Some advertise their poisonous nature with bright colors. For example, hikers often encounter apparently defenseless orange salamanders walking on the forest floor. These are eastern newts in their juvenile red eft stage, and they are extremely poisonous to eat.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ELife Cycle\u003C\/strong\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cu\u003E\u003Cem\u003ESpotted salamander egg mass\u003C\/em\u003E\u003C\/u\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThere\u2019s a great deal of variety in salamander life cycles. They live and breed in various types of water bodies or on the forest floor, and their life cycles may encompass more than one of these habitats. Several Massachusetts salamander species migrate from their overwintering spots in wooded upland areas to breed in vernal pools. These temporary ponds are created by spring rains and snow melts and will dry up by mid-summer, which makes them inhospitable to predators such as fish. Learn more about vernal pools\u00ad\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn most species, breeding involves the male placing a sperm packet called a spermatophore on the ground or on detritus in a pool. The female inserts it into her cloaca to fertilize her eggs, which she may attach to sticks and leaves or under rocks. Some species guard their eggs from predators until they hatch.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMany young salamanders go through an aquatic tadpole stage in which they have visible feathery gills. When they become adults, they may lose gills and gain eyelids and a tongue, as well as the ability to walk on land.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EFood\u003C\/strong\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESalamanders eat many small animals, from insects to spiders to worms. They consume several creatures that people consider pests, such as slugs, mosquito larvae, and flies. They will also sometimes eat other salamanders.\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESalamander Situations \u0026amp; Solutions\u003C\/strong\u003E\u003C\/p\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAmphibians all around the world are in trouble. Three of the 11 salamander species in Massachusetts are listed under the state\u2019s endangered species act. Many salamanders perish when they cross roads to reach their breeding pools, and loss of habitat is another major threat.\u003C\/p\u003E","created_at":"2021-03-01 15:29:25","updated_at":"2021-03-01 15:29:25","vote_count":{"vote_count":1},"totalVotes":1,"num_comments":0,"comments":[],"reactions":[{"reaction_id":1,"reactionable_id":37275895,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":1},{"reaction_id":3,"reactionable_id":37275895,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":1}],"user":{"name":"eeshamaryam","avatar":"https:\/\/img.answers.com\/answ\/image\/upload\/w_avatarSize,h_avatarSize,dpr_2.0\/v1574112807\/avatars\/unicorn.png","username":"eeshamaryam","id":1419961,"user_type":null},"images":[]}],"vote_count":{"votable_id":412437068,"vote_count":122},"meta":[{"id":432457,"question_id":412437068,"key":"language","value":"en","created_at":"2020-09-09T06:37:19.000000Z","updated_at":"2020-09-09T06:37:19.000000Z"}],"user":{"id":13886,"username":"denisblock","name":"Denis term \u0026ldquo;man flu\u0026rdquo; stems from the idea that men are prone to exaggerating the severity of their symptoms when experiencing the common cold or another minor ailment. Although the phrase is most often used in a tongue-in-cheek way, there may be some merit to the male whine. In 2017\u0026rsquo;s customarily playful (but still peer-reviewed) Christmas edition of \u003Cem\u003EThe BMJ\u003C\/em\u003E, professor Kyle Sue \u003Ca href=\u0022https:\/\/www.bmj.com\/company\/newsroom\/man-flu-may-be-real\/\u0022 rel=\u0022nofollow ugc\u0022\u003Epointed to research\u003C\/a\u003E suggesting that men are more susceptible to complications when suffering from an acute respiratory disease. The running water causes your blood to rush to your skins surface. Good blood circulation plays an important role in our health as proper blood circulation contributes to the transferring of nutrients to parts of your body. When your body is lacking good circulation, conditions such as hypertension and varicose veins can occur. sqrt(9) = 3. 3sqrt(3) can be expanded by taking the square of the number out front (3^2) and multiplying it by the number under the root (3) to get the expanded form\/un-simplified version of the root.","created_at":"2020-09-01 02:44:30","updated_at":"2020-09-01 02:44:30","user":{"id":644251,"username":"narkamales","name":"Myriad 3sqrt(3) = sqrt((3^2)(3)) = sqrt((9)(3)) = sqrt(27), not sqrt(9)","created_at":"2020-09-01 02:46:18","updated_at":"2020-09-01 02:46:18","user":{"id":644251,"username":"narkamales","name":"Myriad Jones","avatar":"https:\/\/lh3.googleusercontent.com\/-89VaVkaM7dA\/AAAAAAAAAAI\/AAAAAAAAAAA\/AMZuucl72js4glIBa5hZol33Xgp-a4WnnA\/photo.jpg"}}],"reactions":[{"reaction_id":1,"reactionable_id":36894292,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":1},{"reaction_id":2,"reactionable_id":36894292,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":1},{"reaction_id":3,"reactionable_id":36894292,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":3},{"reaction_id":4,"reactionable_id":36894292,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":1}],"user":{"name":"Keks netbook, text, electronic device","imageable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","imageable_id":36894292,"user_id":643139,"status":"APPROVED","created_at":"2020-08-28T14:49:28.000000Z","updated_at":"2020-08-31T18:55:57.000000Z","full_image_url":"https:\/\/img.answers.com\/answ\/image\/upload\/t_full\/v1598626167\/ugc\/643139\/image_1598626166.jpg"}]},{"id":36894643,"question_id":412270219,"user_id":0,"body":"\u003Cp\u003EHumans acquire a natural language effortlessly at birth. For most hearing people, that\u0026rsquo;s spoken language. We speak and listen. Reading and writing is a technology many of us have learned to use, but it\u0026rsquo;s not our native language. When the technology was in its infancy, relatively speaking\u0026mdash;well into the Common Era\u0026mdash;people, even when reading alone, would speak the words aloud.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003ESome studies show that reading interferes with the visual pathway to the brain, making it harder to visualize the stories depicted as they happen. There are those who like to stress how different people are \u0026lsquo;visual learners\u0026rsquo;, \u0026lsquo;auditory learners\u0026rsquo;, etc. I think much of this is blown out of proportion; there\u0026rsquo;s still no getting around the fact that none of us were born readers, while we acquired natural language from infancy.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EI\u0026rsquo;ve seen comments that audiobooks are not enjoyable because they go too slowly\u0026mdash;one can read faster than one can listen. My perspective, on the other hand, is that if it\u0026rsquo;s not worth getting every word of a book, it\u0026rsquo;s not worth reading at all. A personal experience: I was reading a (print) book, and liked one passage in particular well enough to read it aloud to a friend. In the span of one page, I had found two or three humorous lines that I had missed before when reading it silently; my eye and brain had glanced quickly past them. Even when I read silently, I want to get as much as possible.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThere are of course some types of literature which are better read. Reference works, for instance. Scholarly works never intended to be read aloud, particularly those with footnotes and many parenthetical comments. But some works were never really meant to be read silently (e.g. Shakespeare\u0026rsquo;s plays and sonnets), and yet that is what many people do all the time.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe observation that it\u0026rsquo;s harder to mark portions to go back to is well founded. However, I find that even when I mark portions in print books, I rarely actually go back to them. I\u0026rsquo;m more likely to read the whole thing through again (which isn\u0026rsquo;t very likely considering all the new books I want to read). With audiobooks, on the other hand, you can rate portions of books, even shuffle playback based on which portions I\u0026rsquo;ve listened to least or which I liked best.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EI only recently began to read the Harry Potter series (late to the game!) and I wouldn\u0026rsquo;t have passed up the experience of hearing Stephen Fry read it to me. It is wonderful. In fact, I think the book must have been meant to be read aloud. There are passages of suspense (the countdown till Harry\u0026rsquo;s birthday, for instance) that would be utterly spoilt by a straying eye.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWith audiobooks, I enter a state of \u0026lsquo;flow\u0026rsquo; more often than I do with print books. I especially like to listen while walking; I have found myself wondering where I was when a chapter had finished because of how much I was engrossed in the book\u003C\/p\u003E","created_at":"2020-08-28 17:06:35","updated_at":"2020-08-28 When I act in stage plays, for example, I record my lines and the lines of others that come before and after my lines, into a digital recorder. Sometimes, if the play is really short, I\u0027ll read all of the lines and record them. Then, I\u0027ll listen to it several times a day. is a 1976 American sports drama film directed by John G. Avildsen and both written by and starring Sylvester Stallone. It tells the rags to riches American Dream story of Rocky Balboa, an uneducated but kind-hearted working class Italian-American boxer working in a meat warehouse and as a debt collector for a loan shark in the slums of Philadelphia. Rocky starts out as a small-time club fighter, and later gets a shot at the world heavyweight championship.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe film, made on a budget of just over $1 million and shot in 28 days, was a sleeper hit; it earned $225 million in global box office receipts, becoming the highest-grossing film of 1976, and went on to win three Oscars, including Best Picture. The film received many positive reviews and turned Stallone into a major star. In 2006, the film was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry by the Library of Congress as being \u0022culturally, historically or aesthetically significant\u0022. Rocky is considered to be one of the greatest sports films ever made and was ranked as the second-best in the genre, after Raging Bull, by the American Film Institute in 2008.\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u0022Rocky\u0022 was the first sports film to win Best Picture; the next sports film to win Best Picture was \u0022Chariots of Fire\u0022 (1981), followed by \u0022Million Dollar Baby\u0022 (2004).\u003C\/p\u003E","created_at":"2020-08-26 05:38:53","updated_at":"2020-08-26 05:38:53","vote_count":{"vote_count":1},"totalVotes":1,"num_comments":0,"comments":[],"reactions":[],"user":{"name":"Anonymous","avatar":"https:\/\/img.answers.com\/answ\/image\/upload\/w_avatarSize,h_avatarSize,dpr_2.0\/avatars\/Anonymous\/cyclops_anon-03.png"},"images":[]},{"id":36888949,"question_id":30697458,"user_id":113266,"body":"\u003Cp\u003ERocky was the first sports movie to win an Oscar for Best Picture and it is a 1976 American sports drama film directed by John G.\u003C\/p\u003E","created_at":"2020-08-26 10:32:00","updated_at":"2020-08-26 10:32:00","vote_count":{"vote_count":2},"totalVotes":2,"num_comments":0,"comments":[],"reactions":[{"reaction_id":1,"reactionable_id":36888949,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":1},{"reaction_id":2,"reactionable_id":36888949,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":1},{"reaction_id":3,"reactionable_id":36888949,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":1},{"reaction_id":4,"reactionable_id":36888949,"reactionable_type":"App\\Models\\Answer","count":1}],"user":{"name":"pixigraphics","avatar":"https:\/\/img.answers.com\/answ\/image\/upload\/w_avatarSize,h_avatarSize,dpr_2.0\/v1574112807\/avatars\/troll.png","username":"pixigraphics","id":113266,"user_type":null},"images":[]},{"id":36889109,"question_id":30697458,"user_id":642017,"body":"\u003Cp\u003ERocky\u003C\/p\u003E\u003Cp\u003EWhat was the first sports-themed movie to win the Oscar for Best Picture?         dimension37: pageData && pageData.content && pageData.content.newestAnswer ? pageData.content.newestAnswer : undefined,
        dimension38: pageData && pageData.content && pageData.content.oldestAnswer ? pageData.content.oldestAnswer : undefined,
        dimension39: String(pageData && pageData.content && pageData.content.topicCount ? pageData.content.topicCount : undefined),
        dimension40: String(pageData && pageData.content && pageData.content.answerCount ? pageData.content.answerCount : undefined),
        dimension41: String(pageData && pageData.content && pageData.content.voteCount ? pageData.content.voteCount : undefined),
        dimension42: String(pageData && pageData.content && pageData.content.questionBucket ? pageData.content.questionBucket : undefined),
        dimension44: String(pageData && pageData.content && pageData.content.commentCount ? pageData.content.commentCount : undefined),
        dimension46: String(pageData && pageData.audience_id ? pageData.audience_id : undefined)

    }
    // Dimensions
    // Set them here so that we can access them on both the rails & normal sendEvent functions
    ga('set', dimensions)

    ga('send', 'pageview');
  </script>
  <!-- End Google Analytics -->
  <script async="" defer="" src="https://accounts.google.com/gsi/client">
  </script>

   (function(w){
            w.googletag = w.googletag || {};
            googletag.cmd = googletag.cmd || [];
            w.dataLayer = w.dataLayer || [];
        })(window);
  </script>

   if ('serviceWorker' in navigator) {
            window.addEventListener('load', () => {
                navigator.serviceWorker.register('/pwa.js');
            });
        }

          <h1 class="w-full text-primaryText mb-3 break-words text-h1" property="name">
           <a class="hover:no-underline text-primaryText font-fira font-semibold" href="https://www.answers.com/Q/How_did_chickenpox_get_its_name">
            How did chickenpox get its name
            <!-- -->
            ?
           </a>
          </h1>
          <div class="flex justify-between">
           <div class="flex m-1 items-center">
            <a>
             <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
            </a>
            <a class="hover:no-underline " href="https://www.answers.com/page/wiki-users">
             <p class="text-primaryText text-xs font-serif ml-1">
              Asked by
              <span class="text-primaryColor" property="creator">
               Wiki User
              </span>
             </p>
            </a>
           </div>
           <div class="a4">
            <ul class="a5">
             <li class="a6 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a7 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a8 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a9 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a10 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li>
              <div class="a13 a14">
               739 answers
              </div>
             </li>
            </ul>

          </div>
          <div class="w-full font-serif text-base">
           <div class="markdownStyles" property="content">
            <div>
             <p>
              There are many explanations offered for the origin of the name
              <span>
               chickenpox
              </span>
              :
             </p>
             <ul>
              <li>
               Samuel Johnson suggested that the disease was "less dangerous", thus a "chicken" version of the pox;
              </li>
              <li>
               the specks that appear looked as though the skin was pecked by chickens;
              </li>
              <li>
               the disease was named after chick peas, from a supposed similarity in size of the seed to the lesions;
              </li>
              <li>
               the term reflects a corruption of the Old English word
               <span>
                giccin
               </span>
               , which meant
               <span>
                itching
               </span>
               .
              </li>
             </ul>
            </div>
           </div>
          </div>
          <div class="w-full flex null">
           <div class="ml-auto">
            <button class="h-9 rounded-md p-2 text-base flex items-center bg-tertiary text-white" role="button" tabindex="1">
             <svg class="w-5 h-5 ml-1" viewbox="0 0 24 24">
              <use xlink:href="#create-icon">
              </use>
             </svg>
             <span class="text=-base">
              Answer
             </span>
            </button>
           </div>
          </div>

            <div class="mb-2 flex h-full w-auto">

             </div>

          <h1 class="w-full text-primaryText mb-3 break-words text-h1" property="name">
           <a class="hover:no-underline text-primaryText font-fira font-semibold" href="https://www.answers.com/Q/When_did_organ_music_become_associated_with_baseball">
            When did organ music become associated with baseball
            <!-- -->
            ?
           </a>
          </h1>
          <div class="flex justify-between">
           <div class="flex m-1 items-center">
            <a>
             <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
            </a>
            <a class="hover:no-underline " href="https://www.answers.com/u/curteichmann">
             <p class="text-primaryText text-xs font-serif ml-1">
              Asked by
              <span class="text-primaryColor" property="creator">
               Curt Eichmann
              </span>
             </p>
            </a>
           </div>
           <div class="a4">
            <ul class="a5">
             <li class="a6 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a7 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a8 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a9 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a10 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li>
              <div class="a13 a15">
               127 answers
              </div>
             </li>
            </ul>

          <div class="w-full font-serif text-base">
           <div class="markdownStyles" property="content">
            <div>
             <p>
              While organ music had appeared at hockey rinks in the 1930s, it first bellowed through a baseball stadium on
              <a href="https://www.wbur.org/onlyagame/2016/04/30/organ-mlb-history" rel="ugc nofollow">
               April 26, 1941
              </a>
              . Organist Ray Nelson played 
              <a href="https://www.whig.com/article/20160705/ARTICLE/307059838" rel="ugc nofollow">
               classic and soulful compositions
              </a>
               before the Cubs took on the Cardinals at Wrigley Field. He had to stop before the game started, however, because he was playing copyrighted songs that couldve been picked up by radio broadcasts.
             </p>
             <p>
              The baseball-stadium organ caught on quickly, however; the following season, the Brooklyn Dodgers hired a permanent organist, and their popularity increased through the mid-20th century. Nowadays, theyre commonplace.
             </p>
             <p>
              Oddly enough, the Cubs removed Nelsons organ from the grandstand during a road trip shortly after it first appearedthe copyright liability was just too much for themand organ music wouldnt return to Wrigley until 1967.
             </p>
            </div>
           </div>
          </div>
          <div class="w-full flex null">
           <div class="ml-auto">
            <button class="h-9 rounded-md p-2 text-base flex items-center bg-tertiary text-white" role="button" tabindex="1">

             you can chill it in the freezer for a certain amount of time or
cut it under water

          <h1 class="w-full text-primaryText mb-3 break-words text-h1" property="name">
           <a class="hover:no-underline text-primaryText font-fira font-semibold" href="https://www.answers.com/Q/Why_dont_libraries_smell_like_bookstores">
            Why don't libraries smell like bookstores
            <!-- -->
            ?
           </a>
          </h1>
          <div class="flex justify-between">
           <div class="flex m-1 items-center">
            <a>
             <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
            </a>
            <a class="hover:no-underline " href="https://www.answers.com/u/veronicawilkinson">
             <p class="text-primaryText text-xs font-serif ml-1">
              Asked by
              <span class="text-primaryColor" property="creator">
               Veronica Wilkinson
              </span>
             </p>
            </a>
           </div>
           <div class="a4">
            <ul class="a5">
             <li class="a6 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a7 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a8 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a9 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a10 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li>
              <div class="a13 a17">
               216 answers
              </div>
             </li>
            </ul>
           </div>
          </div>
          <div class="w-full font-serif text-base">
           <div class="markdownStyles" property="content">
            <p>
             I assume youre referring to the difference between the glorious mustiness of a library and the glorious plasticy newness of a bookstore. Thats probably due to the fact that as paper ages, the
             <a href="https://www.popsci.com/science/article/2011-12/fyi-why-do-libraries-have-smell/" rel="ugc nofollow">
              cellulose
             </a>
             within it decays, letting off that sweet, sweet book smell. Bookstore books havent had as much time to decay (unless its a used bookstore), leading to that different smell.
            </p>
           </div>
          </div>
          <div class="w-full flex null">
           <div class="ml-auto">

          <h1 class="w-full text-primaryText mb-3 break-words text-h1" property="name">
           <a class="hover:no-underline text-primaryText font-fira font-semibold" href="https://www.answers.com/Q/Do_animals_name_each_other">
            Do animals name each other
            <!-- -->
            ?
           </a>
          </h1>
          <div class="flex justify-between">
           <div class="flex m-1 items-center">
            <a>
             <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
            </a>
            <a class="hover:no-underline " href="https://www.answers.com/u/danikaabbott">
             <p class="text-primaryText text-xs font-serif ml-1">
              Asked by
              <span class="text-primaryColor" property="creator">
               Danika Abbott
              </span>
             </p>
            </a>
           </div>
           <div class="a4">
            <ul class="a5">
             <li class="a6 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a7 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a8 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a9 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a10 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li>
              <div class="a13 a19">
               164 answers
              </div>
             </li>
            </ul>
           </div>
          </div>
          <div class="w-full font-serif text-base">
           <div class="markdownStyles" property="content">
            <div>
             <p>
              There's no way to speak for all animals, but there is evidence that some animals do have ways to differentiate each other. Some
              <a href="https://www.npr.org/sections/krulwich/2014/04/15/300136332/can-it-be-parrots-name-their-children-and-those-names-like-ours-stick-for-life" rel="ugc nofollow">
               parrots
              </a>
              , for example, seem to identify themselves with specific sets of peeps, and it's possible their parents give them those names. Sweet, right?
             </p>
             <p>
              And parrots aren't the only animals we suspect name each other.
              <a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-23410137" rel="ugc nofollow">
               Dolphins
              </a>
              also have distinctive whistles that function similarly to names. To prove this, researchers played a variety of whistles to a group of dolphins, and the individuals only replied to their signature sound, as if they were calling back when their name had been called.
             </p>
            </div>
           </div>
          </div>
          <div class="w-full flex null">
           <div class="ml-auto">
            <button class="h-9 rounded-md p-2 text-base flex items-center bg-tertiary text-white" role="button" tabindex="1">
             <svg class="w-5 h-5 ml-1" viewbox="0 0 24 24">
              <use xlink:href="#create-icon">
              </use>
             </svg>
             <span class="text=-base">
              Answer
             </span>
            </button>
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div>
         </div>
         <div class="grid grid-cols-1 cursor-pointer justify-start items-start my-4 p-4 bg-white md:rounded shadow-cardGlow">
          <div class="flex justify-between">
           <div class="flex h-full w-auto">
            <div class="mb-2 flex h-full w-auto">
             <div class=" bg-primaryColor hover:bg-primaryLight focus:bg-primaryLight bg-opacity-10 text-primaryColor h-7 mb-2 mr-2 px-2 cursor-pointer rounded flex justify-center items-center " property="breadcrumb">
              WWE World Wrestling Entertainment
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
           <div class="relative inline-block">
            <button class="h-3">
             <svg class="h-6 w-6 transform rotate-90" viewbox="0 0 24 24">
              <use fill="#B6BAC0" xlink:href="#menu-dots">
              </use>
             </svg>
            </button>
           </div>
          </div>
          <h1 class="w-full text-primaryText mb-3 break-words text-h1" property="name">
           <a class="hover:no-underline text-primaryText font-fira font-semibold" href="https://www.answers.com/Q/Who_is_the_longest_reigning_wwe_champion_of_all_time">
            Who is the longest reigning WWE Champion of all time
            <!-- -->
            ?
           </a>
          </h1>
          <div class="flex justify-between">
           <div class="flex m-1 items-center">
            <a>
             <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
            </a>
            <a class="hover:no-underline " href="https://www.answers.com/u/consuelohauck">
             <p class="text-primaryText text-xs font-serif ml-1">
              Asked by
              <span class="text-primaryColor" property="creator">
               Consuelo Hauck
              </span>
             </p>
            </a>
           </div>
           <div class="a4">
            <ul class="a5">
             <li class="a6 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a7 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a8 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>
             </li>
             <li class="a9 a12">
              <a>
               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
              </a>

             <li class="a10 a12">

               <img alt="User Avatar" class="avatar-h-20 avatar-img" src="https://img.answers.com/answ/image/upload/dpr_2.0,w_20,h_20/v1573840443/avatars/default.png"/>
